p: The inhibition of two cholinesterase enzymes (ChEs), acetylcholinesterase (AChE, from Electrophorus electricus, Sigma-Aldrich, SRE020, St Louis, MO, USA) and butyrylcholinesterase (BuChE, from equine serum, Sigma Aldrich, SRE020, St. Louis, MO, USA), both of which are acetylcholine-hydrolyzing enzymes [ 32], was determined by a colorimetric procedure reported by Ellman et al. (1961) [ 33]. The volume used for the inhibition analysis contained 200 μL of phosphate-buffered saline (pH 7.4), 1.5 mM of DTNB, and the EO sample dissolved in DMSO (1% v/ v). The two enzymes AChE and BuChE were dissolved in phosphate-buffered saline (pH 7.4), and 24 mU/mL was taken for each test performed. After 10 min of preincubation, the acetylcholine iodide substrate (1.5 mM) was added to start the reaction. After 30 min at 30 °C, the 96-well microplates were read on a PherastarFS detection kit (BMG Labtech). The measurements were made in triplicate for the EO of leaves and flowers. IC 50 values were calculated using the GNUPLOT online program ( www.ic50.tk, www.gnuplot.info, accessed on 21 January 2021). The reference inhibitor used was donepezil, with IC 50 = 100 nM for AChE and 8500 nM for BuChE. For the analysis, the false-positive results (>100 µg/mL), which may have occurred due to the presence of amine compounds or aldehydes, were excluded [ 34].
